description:
Kyo, an avid swimmer tries his best to keep the high school swimming club going, which is pretty hard when he's the only member. Facing the prospect of the club being closed by the student council, he tries to enlist beautiful Misaki to act in a promo video, shot by his good friend Ryoko, in a bid to start a recruitment drive. She agrees but only if he pilots a mecha under the wing of Celebrum, a resistance organisation fighting to destroy Deutera Areas formed on Earth by the aliens Gards-orm. He agrees but finds it all strangely familiar as if he's done it before...

(Source: Anime News Network)

tags.name: Isekai
tags.description: Features characters being transported into an alternate world setting and having to adapt to their new surroundings.

tags.name: Artificial Intelligence
tags.description: Intelligent non-organic machines that work and react similarly to humans.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Time Manipulation
tags.description: Prominently features time-traveling or other time-warping phenomena.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

tags.name: Virtual World
tags.description: Partly or completely set in the world inside a video game.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Super Robot
tags.description: Prominently features large robots often piloted by hot-blooded protagonists.

tags.name: Swimming
tags.description: Centers around the sport of swimming.

tags.name: CGI
tags.description: Prominently features scenes created with computer-generated imagery.

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Reincarnation
tags.description: Features a character being born again after death, typically as another person or in another world.

tags.name: LGBTQ+ Themes
tags.description: Prominently features characters or themes associated with the LGBTQ+ community, such as sexuality or gender identity.

name.native: メイヴェル・トランスフェイル

node.description:
[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E4%BC%8A%E6%9D%B1%E5%B2%B3%E5%BD%A6) | [Wiki (en)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Takehiko_It%C5%8D)

Takehiko Itou, born in Kitami, Hokkaido Prefecture, Japan, is an illustrator and mangaka best known for his work on [Outlaw Star](https://anilist.co/anime/400/). He was also the primary creative mind behind [Angel Links](https://anilist.co/anime/1226/), the [Future Retro Hero Story](https://anilist.co/manga/33718/) manga, and other works of fiction set in the Toward Stars universe. He also developed the original concept for [NG Knight Ramune & 40](https://anilist.co/anime/2084/).

(Source: Anidb)

Originating from [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/). Known to prescore his works.

Studied under [Satoshi Kon](https://anilist.co/staff/99580/) on [JoJo's Bizarre Adventure](https://anilist.co/anime/666/), [Perfect Blue](https://anilist.co/anime/437/) and [Millenium Actress](https://anilist.co/anime/1033/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/明田川仁)

Affiliated with Magic Capsule, a recording studio led by his father [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062).

As a teenager Yamashita was influenced by the works of [Yoshiyuki Tomino](https://anilist.co/staff/97337/) and [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/), and was inspired to become an animator.

After graduating from Kurashiki Minami High School, he moved to Tokyo to become an animator and joined Bevore. After Bevore's dissolution, he joined Atelier Giga, and from there he joined Project Team Muu. There he was jointly in charge of the character designs, animation direction and storyboards for [Giant Robo the Animation: The Day the Earth Stood Still](https://anilist.co/anime/2321/). The production took nearly 10 years, during which Yamashita gave it his all. After the production was over he started losing his motivation for animation. Though, it sparked again, after having met [Norio Matsumoto](https://anilist.co/staff/100991/) and [Tomohiro Hirata](https://anilist.co/staff/122071/) on the opening animation for a video game called, Gensou Suikogaiden. 

In 2001, Yamashita worked as a key animator on [Spirited Away](https://anilist.co/anime/199/), a [Studio Ghibli](https://anilist.co/studio/21/) feature film. There he was in charge of multiple scenes, most notably Chihiro and Haru's free fall at the end of the movie. This earned him high high praise from [Hayao Miyazaki](https://anilist.co/staff/96870/), and he was thus selected as one of the animation director's for [How's Moving Castle](https://anilist.co/anime/431/). Since then he has served as an animation director on most of Ghibli's movies.

In 2018, Yamashita directed "The Invisible Man," a short film part of the anthology collection [Modest Heroes](https://anilist.co/anime/103887/), produced by [Studio Ponoc](https://anilist.co/studio/6147/). The film won the Newcomer's Award in the Animation Division at the 22nd Japan Media Arts Festival

Married to [Miho Shimogasa](https://anilist.co/staff/116279/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/神宮司訓之)

He does a wide range of design works.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/1178607902522654720)

Originating from Ad Cosmo. Frequent presence in the [Gundam](https://anilist.co/anime/2581/) franchise since 2007.

Itaoka Nishiki is an animator that last worked on Studio Live.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Itaoka1)
